The Subject line says it all.

post_info.post_title: Who Thinks that Hilliary is a "Resident" of New York?

Didn't they buy a house in New York so she could run?

Originally posted by Broker 
 Didn't they buy a house in New York so she could run? 
 
 
 Yep. Do you think Bill and Hillary sleep in the same bed in that house?
 
 Hey that would be a great poll?
Make the poll, make the poll! lol

who cares?
 there were enough people in ny voting for her

Typically your right. This moment could be a very important point in history. 44 liberal Senators are filibustering Judge Miguel Estrada. Hilliary Clinton is one of the Senators leading this block. Right now these Senators are messing with how the Constitution determines the members of the Judicial branch of government. Basically there is some really freaky experimentation going on the Constituion right now. Hilliary is leading the experiment.

I chose political trickery to get her into office.
 
 
there were enough people in ny voting for her

 
 Again, I say political trickery to get her into office, namely election fraud.

Technically, Hillary is a resident of New York. If she were not, she would be unable to represent NY in the Senate.
 
 However, I believe it was political trickery.

This is a perfect example of what kind of people lived in the Whitehouse durring the prior administration. We have people who believe in the right thing is what you are legally allowed to get away with, remember they are lawyers. 
 
 Did Hillary ever put her kid in a local school in NY? Do the people at the local grocery store know Hillary? Does she know where the post office is in her neighborhood? The "residence" that Hillary used to legally claim is nothing more than a rich persons post office box.
OK fine. Who thinks Dick Cheney was a "resident" of wyoming when he ran for vp?

I agree that Dick came out of the same slime bucket as Bill and Hillary.
 
 http://thebase.weblogger.com/stories/storyReader$3263
But Vice President is not a state election, it is a national one. It doesn't matter what state Cheney was from, as long as he lived in the U.S. For Hillary, she had to live in NY to run for Senate.
OK I revise that again. Dick came out of a mold bucket, not a slime bucket. I believe molds are a little higher order than slime.
oh, the texas/wyoming thing would be irrelevant IF it weren't for the 12th amendment.

I still don't see how it is relevant. The 12th amend. says that the electors can't vote for two people from the same state as themselves. It doesn't say that the rest can't vote for two people from the same state.
 
 Please correct me if I'm wrong here, but I researched it.

I don't understand why this should be an issue. It seems like we are looking at the problem of what's reasonable and what the law says. She's  obviously a LEGAL residence of NY and met all the requirements to run for office ; some people may object to it, but the law doesn't! That's all that's necessary.
 
 This is similar to the question of whether Bush should be president. The law says he should, so he is, despite that over half of the population doesn't think he should be.

Can you name the last President to be elected with over half of the population? It was Reagan in 1984. Bush Sr. couldn't do it in '88, Clinton couldn't do it in '92 or '96.
 
 We elect the president with the electoral college. And until that is changed, winning the electoral college is the ONLY way to win the presidency.
I take that back. I meant "the majority of the population".

Not really. See for yourself 
 
 http://www.m-w.com/cgi-bin/dictionary
 
 4 : the group or political party whose votes preponderate
 
 Majority doesn't have to mean over a half! In some cases it can, but it doesn't have to.

In candidate voting theory, majority always means over half; plurality means more than any other candidate. The definition you provided relates to group voting theory, which is where you have more than two groups of voters. That's a totally different issue that I don't want to get into.
 
 As I said before, the last president to receive a majority of the vote was Reagan in 1984. Gore did receive a plurality of the popular vote, but he did not win the electoral college, which is how we elect the president in this country.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Who Thinks that Hilliary is a "Resident" of New York?
